From the company’s large e-mail database, a second random sample of <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> e-mails known to be spam was selected. Each e-mail was randomly assigned to one of the three filters. The segmented bar graph shows the distribution of the number of e-mails correctly classified as spam and incorrectly classified as legitimate for each filter. (b) Write a few sentences describing what the graph reveals about the association between filter and classification accuracy among the <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> spam e-mails.

(c) For each filter, give a statistical reason why the technology department might choose to implement the filter across the e-mail inboxes of the entire company. Do not perform an inferential procedure.

The technology department plans to use the sample data to investigate whether there is convincing statistical evidence, at <math alttext="alpha equals 0.02" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, that the proportion of legitimate e-mails that would be correctly classified by Filter <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than the proportion of spam e-mails that would be correctly classified by Filter <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.(d) Name the appropriate test and state, in words, the hypotheses.
(e) State the conditions for the appropriate test, and explain why the conditions are met.

(f) The test statistic for the appropriate test is <math alttext="2.268" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.268</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> (legitimate minus spam). Based on the result of the hypothesis test, what conclusion should the technology department make? Justify your answer.
